Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an Illumina HiSeq2000 as a core sequencing instrument for genomics and gene expression research
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation award supports the purchase of an Illumina HiSeq2500 DNA sequencing instrument for the Genomics Core Facility at Penn State's University Park campus. Sequencing of DNA is a key component of modern life sciences research. In the last decade, technologies for DNA sequencing have advanced at an astonishing rate. In that time frame, data output per instrument "run" has increased by more than a trillion-fold. Consequently, the amount of DNA information available has skyrocketed, enabling revolutionary advances across all of the biosciences. The Illumina HiSeq2500 is the most powerful sequencing instrument available to date, both in terms of data output per unit time, and cost per DNA-base sequenced. Its very high quality, relatively long read lengths, and well-established sequencing chemistry allow the maximum experimental flexibility. It is capable of generating DNA sequence data to allow de novo genome assemblies, as well as re-sequencing and transcriptome studies. Installation of this instrument into the Genomics Facility will significantly enhance life science research at Penn State and beyond, particularly in three broad areas: Genomics and gene expression of non-model organisms, genomics of multispecies interactions, and regulation of gene expression. Given the flexibility and robust performance of this instrument, it is likely that many additional, as yet unforeseen areas of study will be enhanced by this instrument.

This instrument's capabilities will dramatically enhance life sciences research at Penn State. In addition, it will enhance interdisciplinary scientific training for Penn State researchers at the undergraduate, graduate, and post-doctoral levels. It's use and data will be integrated into existing hands-on graduate training programs and courses, and used as part of the regular series of workshops offered by the Genomics Core Facility. Access and training will be provided, through several existing programs, to several populations of students who are currently under-represented in the scientific enterprise. Experiments conducted on this instrument will also be used to enhance Penn State's continuing involvement with a consortium of predominantly undergraduate institutions for scientific training.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project provided funds to purchase a very high-capacity DNA sequencing instrument, as well as computer hardware needed to operate the instrument and handle the data. The instrument is housed at Penn State University's University Park campus, and is used by a wide group of Penn State scientists.

DNA sequencing refers to the process of identifying the specific order of 'letters' in DNA. This information can be used to reconstruct the entire set of genetic instructions for an organism. It can also be used to determine which genes are active in a certain specimen. The technology that enables DNA sequencing has undergone a revolution over the last decade. Using older technology the first sequenced human genome in the late 90s to early 00s cost well over a billion dollars and took many years. The Illumina HiSeq that was purchased in this award can generate the same amount of data in a week for a cost of a few thousand dollars. This extraordinary capacity has enabled a very wide range of genetic and biological research at Penn State. Below are just a few examples out of the hundreds of research projects that have been completed or are in progress using this instrument.

1. Sequencing of the giraffe genome. This project provided the first complete genome sequence of a giraffe, an iconic and endangered species. This was a collaboration between Penn State and researchers from the Nelson Mandela Institute in Tanzania. Scientifically, the project is enabling determination of the genes involved in making the giraffe's neck so extraordinarily long in a very short evolutionary time-scale. In terms of broader societal impacts, this project has engaged international cooperation, provided an opportunity for African scientists to work on a whole genome sequencing project, and it is hoped will help to spur more vigorous conservation efforts to preserve giraffe populations.

2. Analyzing expressed genes in the parasite that causes malaria (Plasmodium). This project may help to develop new therapies against this major scourge of humanity.

3. Sequencing DNA from squashes and gourds. This study has demonstrated the power of human domestication on the survival of this entire lineage.

These are just a few of literally hundreds of projects at Penn State that this instrument has enabled. Many of the projects that this instrument has enabled involve undergraduate student education, graduate student education, and public science outreach.
